pullRequest.body:
Also adds some useful instances and lemmas about the unit interval.

The subsquares version will be useful for Van Kampen.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#7976~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

None of my comments above are intended to be blocking, this is outside an area I'm all that familiar with; they were intended as discussion points for (or to be ignored by) another reviewer who knows better.

:v: alreadydone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7048621772/job/19185189207)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7048621772/job/19185188836)

bors d+
Thanks for the review!
bors d+
I think this docstring should be a little more specific.

This lemma looks a bit misleading! Perhaps to help the reader:
```suggestion
lemma univ_eq_Icc : (univ : Set I) = Icc (0 : I) (1 : I) := by
  ext ⟨t, t0, t1⟩; simp_rw [mem_univ, true_iff]; exact ⟨t0, t1⟩
```
It would be nice to have another lemma via `''` where the RHS lives in `ℝ`, but you can declare that out of scope

Do you mean [Set.image_subtype_val_Icc](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Intervals/OrdConnected.html#Set.image_subtype_val_Icc)? (Apparently we lack the OrdConnected instance on Icc though.) That lemma would not be specific to unit interval; this one is special as not every interval has Zero and One.
I think it would follow from that lemma, yes; so `Subtype.val '' (univ : Set I) = Icc 0 1`.

Oh I shouldn't be mentioning [Set.image_subtype_val_Icc](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Intervals/OrdConnected.html#Set.image_subtype_val_Icc). Your lemma is just [Set.image_univ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.image_univ) trans [Subtype.range_val](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Subtype.range_val) (note `I` is abbrev of `Icc 0 1`).
It's `StrictAnti`, isn't it?
done!
nit: I think you can get here even faster via `Involutive.bijective`
golfed and added `involutive_symm`
This docstring seems a bit misleading, since for large `n` these are not equally spaced after all.
expanded

```suggestion
/-- Any open cover `c` of a closed interval `[a, b]` in ℝ can be refined to
  a finite partition into subintervals. -/
```
I can't remember: do we prefer writing this with `tendsto`?
It should be equivalent to `Tendsto (addNsmul h δ) atTop (pure b)` but I think the spelling is too high-tech here ...
I'm not familiar enough with the use of `Tendsto` to know whether this is too high-tech

[Filter.EventuallyEq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/Basic.html#Filter.EventuallyEq) would lead to a shorter statement but I still don't see the point of packing and unpacking the definition, especially since [Filter.mem_atTop_sets](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Filter/AtTopBot.html#Filter.mem_atTop_sets) isn't defeq.

Is this more or less convenient as:
```suggestion
    (hc₁ : ∀ i, IsOpen (c i)) (hc₂ : univ ⊆ ⋃ i, c i) :
    ∃ (n : ℕ) (t : Fin n.succ → Icc a b), t 0 = a ∧ t n = b ∧ Monotone t ∧
      ∀ n : Fin n, ∃ i, Icc (t n.castSucc) (t n.succ) ⊆ c i := by
```

Not sure what benefits that has; the current formulation is quite convenient for doing [induction](https://gist.github.com/alreadydone/c88265c99c73fa822d48e1abfd01282f#file-homotopylifting-lean-L207-L208) [over Nat](https://gist.github.com/alreadydone/c88265c99c73fa822d48e1abfd01282f#file-homotopylifting-lean-L281-L282).
The main benefit is that the "junk" values after `t m` go away.
And you can probably do one of the tuple inductions on `t`, but maybe it's not convenient

You could argue that the last gap may not be the same as the others so there's "junk" there as well :) We could make it a finite strict monotone sequence by truncating, and if `α` is a field (or DivisibleBy Nat) we can get a genuinely *equally spaced* finite sequence with arbitrarily small gap, but I don't have uses for them. I consider this as a technical lemma so the important thing is that it applies easily (if stated in terms of Fin people would have to look into the less familiar Fin API), and people who need the stronger versions can get them by proving more about `addNsmul`.
I don't think is a great name. We usually don't name theorem using the main proof ingredient, we try to describe the statement. This also applies to the next two statements.

Indeed; I had the impression it's roughly equivalent to the Lebesgue number lemma, but there's no obvious reverse implication. Changed to `exists_monotone_Icc_subset_open_cover_Icc/unitInterval(_prod_self)`.
This is `Icc_bot_top.symm`.
Thanks

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: partition into subintervals/squares adapted to an open cover
